headline: AG candidate Crossman vows to fight government corruption in Fremont visit
author: Daniel Carson
sentences: "We deserve better in this state," Crossman, a state representative from Parma, said as he talked about political redistricting, the FirstEnergy corruption scandal and how he plans to connect with voters ahead of the November election.

Crossman said U.S. Rep. Tim Ryan, an Ohio Democrat running for U.S. Senate to fill Rob Portman's seat, had conducted a strong campaign for two years and would be a boon to other state Democrats campaigning for other elected positions.

A former Parma City Council member, Crossman has pushed for transparency and reforms after former Ohio House Speaker Larry Householder and four others were arrested in July 2020 in connection with a $1 billion nuclear plant bailout.
Thursday, Crossman told supporters political redistricting and gerrymandering of Ohio's statehouse and congressional districts showed a lack of accountability from legislators to the state's voters.
He said he expected Democrats to win in Ohio this year because he thought there would ultimately be fair political redistricting maps approved by the Ohio Supreme Court.
That was the message Crossman delivered to supporters Thursday, as the Democratic candidate for Ohio attorney general visited Fremont and spoke at the Strand Theater.
He said he wanted to get voters to look beyond party labels and hoped people would check candidates' records, character and what they plan to do in office.
He said the repeated problems with redistricting maps shows a pattern of Republican legislators denying the right of voters to choose elected officials.
Overall, the Democratic candidate said voters were frustrated and didn't believe the state government was working for them.
